importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework is now delayed until late 2026, meaning global shipping emissions regulation will not be enforced for at least 12 months.

keyTakeAways: United States President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting a global carbon tax for shipping emissions.
The International Maritime Organization (IMO) voted to postpone formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months, despite prior approval in April 2025.
The NZF would have been the first global carbon-pricing system for shipping, charging $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions.
The decision comes amid a broader U.S. policy reversal on climate change, with Trump promoting fossil fuels and deregulating clean energy initiatives.
Countries like China, the EU, Brazil, Britain, and Singapore had previously supported the framework, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed it.
The International Chamber of Shipping expressed disappointment over lack of clarity, stressing the need for investment in decarbonization technologies.
Vanuatu’s climate minister criticized the delay as 'unacceptable' given the urgency of climate change, emphasizing the role of international law.
Climate change is already impacting maritime safety through altered ocean currents and more frequent storms, making emissions reduction urgent.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has delayed the formal adoption of its Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months, following a public threat from U.S. President Donald Trump to impose sanctions on countries supporting a global carbon tax on shipping emissions. The NZF, which would have charged ships $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions, was initially approved in April 2025 but now faces a significant setback due to political pressure. Countries such as China, the EU, Brazil, and Britain had previously backed the plan, while Russia, Saudi Arabia, Argentina, and Singapore voted to postpone it. The decision has been criticized by environmental leaders, shipping industry representatives, and climate vulnerable nations like Vanuatu, who argue it undermines urgent efforts to combat climate change. The delay reflects broader U.S. policy reversal on climate change, with Trump promoting fossil fuels and deregulating clean energy. The IMO, responsible for regulating international shipping and pollution, now faces a pivotal moment in global climate governance.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
